Money can buy happiness, but it alone doesn't make you happy. When people say ''money doesn't buy'you happiness'' they usually say that for people who marry for money or want money to get everything they want.
But the truth is that money is simply a tool that helps you do and get what will really makes you happy easier. And that is being around what you love most.
This can include family, friends or a specific location. I had a teacher once who got rid of a lot of wealth because he didn't need it. He only needed a little money to get and be what made him truly happy.

So please don't think that more money=more happiness. Because it doesn't. Not only will you get used to having a lot of money, which will result in you not being as happy as you were when you got the money, but when you have a lot of money then more money doesn't make a difference.
For example: getting a car is amazing. So it 2 or 3 cars. But when you have 50 cars then another 3 wouldn't make much of a difference in your happiness. In fact, you will get so used to having a lot that you don't have much else to gain. This will result in a DECREASE in happiness because you gained so much in your life that reaching a point where that gain keeps slowing down will frustrate you.

A limo and the most expensive clothes don't make you happy. What makes you happy is being around what you love most. Money is tool that will make achieving that easier. It gets you through life. But money=/=being happy. That happiness depends on what you do with it and knowing how much you need to be happy. For some people, a little money still makes them happy.

The quote is misleading because it assumes that money and happiness have nothing to do with each other. Of course money can't directly buy or cause happiness but it can help attain happiness. Money can get you opportunities, comfort, quality of life, safety, shelter, food, pleasure, health, peace; all of which lead to some sort of gratification, or happiness. What the quote is really implying is that even if you have all of those things you won't necessarily be happy, you could still be depressed or miserable about something. If you don't have enough money to buy what you need - food, shelter, medical care, for instance, then YES! money can go a long way towards buying happiness.

If there's a material thing that you just really want (not wanting because a clever ad told you you should want it) then yes again. I recall a slow night at the cab company. I lucked into a run where the guy gave me a very nice tip. Enough to pay for a swiss steak dinner at a local diner. This was something I'd been hankering for and lacked the skill to make for myself. That evening, happiness sold for $8 and change. (plus tip, of course)  And it remains a solid memory of happiness for me.

But if you have all the material stuff you could possibly need, but lack a good friend, or the love of your life, attempts at buying happiness are most likely going to fail in a very bad way. Spending money on others Only works if it is done in the true spirit of generosity. Friendship & love can only be earned.

True generosity is best served with wisdom & knowledge. Don't try to buy someone something you think you'd want or something you want therm to have. Take the time to find out what would make them happiest. Perhaps instead of the fancy red sports car, they'd prefer a years worth of tuition & books. Or vice versa. Learn how to listen! The satisfaction of seeing true joy in the face of someone you care about is worth the effort. And That is buying happiness.

I'll finish the thought by hoping that the uber rich one day realize that they have enough and then some. And that they can buy themselves a bit of happiness by seeing to it that some other people at least have enough.

V.S. Ramachandran explains this in his book "The Tell Tale Brain."  It has to do with the perception of harm followed by the alleviation of that perception.  Animals show their teeth when they are confronted by a predator, right?  When someone approaches us with the intent of tickling us, we can't help but start smiling, even if we do not want to be tickled.  Tickling resembles a predatory behavior, but we now that it is harmless.  This cognitive dissonance causes the laughing response.  Get it?

The scientific consensus is that astral projection is not real.  It's just a powerful illusion that takes place entirely inside your brain.  That is why nobody has ever been able to project into another room and identify what is in there to a team of scientists.
But if you want a fringe scientific view on it, you can search My Big T.O.E. on youtube and watch the lecture of a scientist who believes in it.

Assuming you mean physical addiction: It's when you put too much of a chemical into your body. You body then slows down production of that chemical to compensate. Then, to get the same high, you'd need to have that much chemical + what your body is no longer producing. This makes your body produce even less.
This continues until you quit, are completely physically dependant (your body isn't making enough chemicals anymore)...or you die.
